title: Lab with a vertical marble launcher to find g

content.question: Read each part carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. Students are going to perform an experiment to determine the acceleration due to gravity, <math alttext="g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, in the labusing the setup shown above. They are expected to find <math alttext="g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> by plotting their data in a graph. The students have access to equipment commonly found in a high school physics laboratory, but the experiment must use the setup as shown above, which includes a vertical launcher with a spring coil of relaxed length <math alttext="l sub 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and known spring constant <math alttext="k" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and a sphere with mass <math alttext="m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, as shown. The sphere can be pushed down and secured with a pin, which can be pulled to launch the sphere. The vertical position of the pin can be changed. There is negligible friction between the coil, the sphere and the vertical walls of the launcher. (a) Briefly identify each quantity to be measured, the symbol used to represent that quantity, and the equipment that would be used to measure the quantity.

They are expected to find <math alttext="g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> by plotting their data in a graph. The students have access to equipment commonly found in a high school physics laboratory, but the experiment must use the setup as shown above, which includes a vertical launcher with a spring coil of relaxed length <math alttext="l sub 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and known spring constant <math alttext="k" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and a sphere with mass <math alttext="m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, as shown. The sphere can be pushed down and secured with a pin, which can be pulled to launch the sphere. The vertical position of the pin can be changed. There is negligible friction between the coil, the sphere and the vertical walls of the launcher. (a) Briefly identify each quantity to be measured, the symbol used to represent that quantity, and the equipment that would be used to measure the quantity.

(b) Briefly describe the procedure to be used to determine the acceleration due to gravity, <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Provide enough detail so that another student could replicate the experiment, including any steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty. As needed, use the symbols you defined in part (a).

(c) Which quantities (raw data or calculated from the data) would be graphed on the vertical and horizontal axes to produce a graph that could be used to determine the acceleration due to gravity, <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(d) Describe which information from the graph described in part (c) would be used and how it would be used to determine the acceleration due to gravity, <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(e) In a second experiment students observe that the friction between the sphere and inner wall of the launcher is not negligible, because the sphere rolls while being pushed. If students follow the same procedure and analysis as described in part (b) through part (d) without taking friction into account, will the magnitude of acceleration due to gravity <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> obtained in this second experiment be greater than, less than, or equal to the magnitude of <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> obtained in the initial experiment?
